p: Gelatinization temperatures and enthalpies of flours are presented in Table 4. According to Krueger, Knutson [ 52] and Tester [ 53], gelatinization temperatures are related to characteristics of the starch granule, such as the degree of crystallinity, starch composition and molecular structure of amylopectin. Gelatinization describes the irreversible disruption of molecular order within a starch granule when heated in excess water. The (T 0) of raw flour, i.e. 77.1 and 76.9°C, was comparable to 76.8°C reported by Sirivongpaisal [ 54], but higher than the 67.4–71.2°C reported by Kaptso, Njintang [ 34].
